<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>

<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_generic_dev_dma_map:
```c
int metal_generic_dev_dma_map(struct metal_bus *bus,
			     struct metal_device *device,
			     uint32_t dir,
			     struct metal_sg *sg_in,
			     int nents_in,
			     struct metal_sg *sg_out)
{
	int i;
	(void)bus;
	(void)device;

	if (sg_out != sg_in)
		memcpy(sg_out, sg_in, nents_in*(sizeof(struct metal_sg)));
	for (i = 0; i < nents_in; i++) {
		if (dir == METAL_DMA_DEV_W) {
			metal_cache_flush(sg_out[i].virt, sg_out[i].len);
		}
		metal_cache_invalidate(sg_out[i].virt, sg_out[i].len);
	}

	return nents_in;
}
```

suspicious_frags:
if (sg_out != sg_in)
		memcpy(sg_out, sg_in, nents_in*(sizeof(struct metal_sg)));
explanation: Only the memcpy call and subsequent indexed accesses of sg_out[i] need investigation with respect to MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 because the rule concerns use of <string.h> functions and any resulting accesses beyond the bounds of the referenced objects. The memcpy invocation (including the computed size nents_in*(sizeof(struct metal_sg))) can produce out-of-bounds accesses, integer/size overflow, or be unsafe for overlapping source/destination; the loop that follows dereferences sg_out[i] for nents_in elements and must be checked for valid allocation and bounds. Other fragments (function signature, (void)bus; (void)device; declaration int i; return nents_in; and the unrelated long sizes[max_sizes]) do not call string.h functions nor perform memory copies via those APIs, so they are not relevant to Rule 21.17 and do not need investigation for this specific rule.
